chunks.en: Discovered during Chinese New Year that rural people are superstitious about barefoot doctors.

I have a skin condition, similar to ringworm, and have seen doctors at reputable tertiary hospitals in Shanghai and Beijing. They say it's atopic dermatitis, which is incurable and can only be relieved.

After telling my family, they wanted to take me to a Yang doctor in a rural clinic, saying that his medical skills are superb and that he can cure many conditions that large hospitals cannot.

I didn't really believe it, but out of politeness, I went with them. Goodness, the medication is very strong. I have to get two injections every day, and one packet of Western medicine before and after each meal, with about 10 pills in each packet, a total of 4 or 5 different types of pills.

I need to stick to this for a week.

The problem is that I have to go back to work in a couple of days, and I don't really want to take leave to get treatment in the village. I'm in a dilemma now, sigh.

Are rural doctors really better than medical Ph.D.s in big cities?
I highly doubt it. I don't know why people in my hometown trust barefoot doctors so much and don't go to regular county hospitals.
City doctors' medications take longer to work because they fully consider the consequences...
They try to help the body naturally digest the virus and follow the laws of nature.

chunks.en: Barefoot doctors' approach is like chemotherapy, using medication to kill a large number of cells, regardless of whether it's good or bad, as long as you can walk. If you die from it, as long as the time interval is long, it's not their responsibility. If you really die in a few days, they can just run away.
Aggressively using hormones for skin diseases will definitely relieve the symptoms, but do you want to consider the risk of femoral head necrosis?
A doctor who didn't even graduate from a third-tier medical university is a complete quack.

If a barefoot doctor has a license, they are a legal village doctor. They are definitely not as good as doctors in big cities, and there may even be some problems, but doctors in big cities will definitely not stay in the village. So, the people who stay in the village and the barefoot doctors are each taking what they need. The reason for not going to the county hospital is the same as the reason for not living in the county town, possibly because they can't afford it or aren't used to it.

So the only unconventional and awkward thing in this matter is actually the original poster, who has gone out but not really gone out. On the one hand, they don't believe in barefoot doctors, and on the other hand, they are being treated out of 'politeness'.

PS: In the future, the original poster will become a new case in the mouths of the villagers to prove the doctor's awesomeness: 'Our village's [original poster's name], who couldn't be cured by big hospitals in Beijing and Shanghai, had to come back to find Doctor Yang'.
Don't believe it.
Born confused, sick confused, die confused.
I hope everyone will not be confused.
I have the right to speak on this. The three magic weapons of rural doctors are antibiotics, hormones, and painkillers.
@0xABCD It took almost a year, and the price was saying goodbye to smoking, drinking, and staying up late forever.

I also have a skin condition: currently lichen planus, which has not been cured for more than 10 years.
I came to the Air Force General Hospital in Beijing and used topical Western medicine for 10 days, and it went away.
The Air Force General Hospital's medicine is self-made.
It is not sold on the market.
Later, it relapsed, and the doctor at the Air Force General Hospital advised me to go to Xiyuan Hospital to see a Chinese medicine doctor, using both topical application and internal regulation.
Now I'm cured, I don't smoke, drink, or stay up late, and it hasn't relapsed, and I'm married.
Before, no one wanted me on blind dates because of this, because at that time it was basically all over my body.
